facts.text: Writ Petition No. 94 of 1972 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution challenging Trade Notice dated 29 January 1972.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 94 of 1972. Under Article 32 of the Constitution for the enforcement of fundamental rights. K. Garg, S. C. Aggarwala, for the petitioner. T. Desai, B. D. Sharma, M. N. Shroff, for respondents Nos. 1 and 2. Sen, O. C. Mathur, J. B. Dadachanji Ravinder Narain, for respondent No. 3. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by RAY, C.J. This petition under Article 32 of the Constitution challenges the Trade Notice dated 29 January, 1972 referred to as the impugned numberice.

facts.text: Trade Notice dated 29 January 1972 canalises export of all grades and varieties of mica except manufactured and fabricated mica, micanite, reconstituted mica, mica powder and mica paper through Minerals and Metals Trading Corporation of India Ltd., effective from 24 January 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned Notice is issued by the Controller of Imports Exports under the aforesaid statutory provisions. Under Trade Notice dated 13 March, 1968 reproducing Export Control Order No. 1/68-EIC dated 8 March, 1968 export of mica including mica splittings, blocks, scrap waste which are included in the list of items in Part B of Shedule I of the Export Control Order was allowed on merits. Under the impugned numberice the export of mica is decided to be under the scheme to canalise the export of all grades and variety of mica, excepting manufactured and fabricated mica, micanite, reconstituted mica, mica powder and mica paper through the Minerals and Metals Trading Corporation of India Ltd.  hereinafter referred to as the Corporation . The impugned Notice further states that this canalisation of export scheme will be effective from 24 January 1972.

facts.text: Mica scrap and mica waste included as item No. 22A of Part B of Schedule 1 of the Export Control Order 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 3 1  of the 1968 Order provides that numberperson shall export goods of the description specified in Schedule 1 of the 1968 Order except under and in accordance with the licence granted by the Central Government or by an officer specified, in Shedule I I of the 1968 Order. Mica scrap and mica waste are included as item No. 22 a  of Part B of Schedule 1 of the 1968 Order. Part B of Schedule 1 of the 1968 Order enumerates the items the export of which is allowed on merits or subject to ceilings or other companyditions to be specified form time to time.

facts.text: Pre-canalisation commitment category allows export if contract entered before 24 January 1972 or telegraphic offer and acceptance prior, and irrevocable LC opened before 24 January 1972.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to cases falling under pre- canalisation companymitment category the port licensing authorities may allow export if the shipping documents produced by the exporters are accompanied by documents showing that the companytract was entered into with the foreign buyers before 24 January, 1972 or telegraphic offer and acceptance is dated prior to 24 January, 1972 and irrevocable letter of credit at sight is opened in a Bank in India or in foreign companyntry before 24 January, 1972.

facts.text: Exporters to furnish particulars of pre-canalisation contracts on or before 15 February 1972 to Controller of Imports Exports.

anchor.surface_text: The, impugned Notice further states that exporters who wish to avail themselves of the pre-canalisation companymitment category are to furnish particulars on or before 15 February. 1972 at the office of the Controller of Imports Exports. The particulars are first, full statement showing quantity, grade of the mica  blocks, splittings, companydensor films, mica scrap and factory cuttings , delivery period, name of the buyers, companytract number and date with particulars of letter of credit number and date and second, quantities already shipped tinder these companytracts and balance quantities to be, shipped.

facts.text: Corporation issued Press Notice prescribing procedure for exporters under Canalisation Scheme.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the decision numberified under the impugned Notice the Corporation issued immediately thereafter a Press Notice on export of mica prescribing the procedure to be adopted by the exporters taking recourse to the Canalisation Scheme.

facts.text: Petitioner wrote to respondent giving details of nine contracts accepted from overseas buyers prior to 24 January 1972, some partially shipped.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequent to the Press Note the petitioner wrote to the respondent and gave details of companytracts accepted by the petitioner from over-seas buyers prior to the canalisation of export scheme which came into effect on 24 January, 1972. The petitioner stated that in some cases shipment had been made and there was a balance to be shipped subsequent to 24 January, 1972. The petitioner gave details of nine such companytracts.

facts.text: Export Clarification Circular No. 3 of 1972 dated 17 April 1972 allows exports where LC opened before 31 March 1972 even if shipment period expired, up to 30 June 1972.

anchor.surface_text: After the publication of the impugned Notice several exporters represented that they did number understand the import of restrictions and went on opening letters of credit with respect to companytracts entered into between the exporters and the foreign buyers. The Government with a view to lessen the hardships on the traders issued an Export Clarification Circular No. 3 of 1972 dated 17 April 1972 that in respect of cases where fetter of credit was opened before 31 March, 1972 but the period of shipment had expired, exports might be allowed in the name of private parties provided the shipment is made number beyond 30 June, 1972.

facts.text: Trade Notice dated 20 April 1972 modifies canalisation scheme to allow shipments up to 30 June 1972 against contracts prior to 24 January 1972 even if LC not opened before that date.

anchor.surface_text: The State issued another Trade Notice on 20 April. 1972. This April 1972 Notice is also impeached. Under the April Notice which can be described as the second impugned Notice it is stated that the canalisation scheme Provided in the impugned Notice of 29 January, 1972 is modified to the extent that shipments will be allowed up to 30 June, 1972 against subsisting companytracts for all grades and varieties of mica which had been executed prior to 24 January. 1972 and ill respect of which letters of credit have number been opened prior to 24 January, 1972.

facts.text: Representations received: Bihar Mica Exporters Association dated 25 January 1972, Mica Chamber of Commerce Gudur dated 9 February 1972, Bihar Mica Exporters Association dated 16 March 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The three representations received by the Ministry are from the Bihar Mica Exporters Association dated 25 January, 1972, the Mica Chamber of Commerce, Gudur, Andhra Pradesh dated 9 February, 1972 and the Bihar Mica Exporters Association dated 16 March, 1972.

facts.text: Petitioner claims canalisation scheme transfers business and goodwill to Corporation, outside purview of Act.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner challenged the canalisation of export scheme on the following grounds. First, it is number a canalisation scheme. It is in fact a scheme to transfer the business of the petitioner and goodwill in favour of the Corporation which is outside the purview of the Act.

facts.text: Petitioner claims scheme causes loss of foreign exchange, profit, and enables buyers to sue for breach, violating Article 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: Second, the scheme is an unreasonable restriction in so far as it results in loss of foreign exchange, loss of profit and enables company- tracting foreign buyers to avoid the companytract and sue the petitioner for breach of the companytract. Therefore, the scheme violates Article 19 1   g  of the Constitution

facts.text: Court holds canalisation scheme pursuant to section 3(1)(a) of 1947 Act and clause 6(1) of 1968 Order.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of canalisation of export through the Corporation is pursuance to section 3 1   a  of the 1947 Act and clause 6 1  of the 1968 Order. The 1947 Act companyfers power to restrict, companytrol or prohibit or otherwise companytrol imports and exports.

facts.text: Corporation charges 1% of FAS value as service charges.

anchor.surface_text: The Corporation will realise from the local suppliers as Service charges number exceeding 1 of the FAS value.

facts.text: Petition dismissed by the Court.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons, the companytentions of the petitioner fail. The petition is dismissed.

facts.text: Export of mica allowed on merits under Trade Notice dated 13 March 1968 and Export Control Order No. 1/68-EIC dated 8 March 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Under Trade Notice dated 13 March, 1968 reproducing Export Control Order No. 1/68-EIC dated 8 March, 1968 export of mica including mica splittings, blocks, scrap waste which are included in the list of items in Part B of Shedule I of the Export Control Order was allowed on merits.

facts.text: Several exporters opened LCs after impugned notice as they did not understand restrictions.

anchor.surface_text: After the publication of the impugned Notice several exporters represented that they did number understand the import of restrictions and went on opening letters of credit with respect to companytracts entered into between the exporters and the foreign buyers.

facts.text: Exporters reported consignments worth Rs. 70 lakhs under processing for shipment by 31 Jan 1972, Rs. 130 lakhs ready in Feb, etc.

anchor.surface_text: The difficulties pointed out were that export companysignments worth about Rs. 70 lakhs in the names of different exporters supported by valid companytracts and letters of credit were under processing through Joint Chief Controller of Imports Exports and Customs at Calcutta Port for shipment within 31 January, 1972. ... Goods worth about Rs. 150 lakhs were under manufacturing process against orders and letters of credit for shipment in March, 1972.

facts.text: Mica powder excluded from canalisation to develop nascent mica powder industry.

anchor.surface_text: The affidavit evidence on behalf of the State is that the exclusion of mica powder from the canalisation scheme is to develop mica power industry in our companyntry, because this industry is developing and is practically nascent in growth.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by RAY, C.J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by RAY, C.J.

holdings.text: The scheme of canalisation of export through the Corporation is pursuance to section 3 1   a  of the 1947 Act and clause 6 1  of the 1968 Order.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of canalisation of export through the Corporation is pursuance to section 3 1   a  of the 1947 Act and clause 6 1  of the 1968 Order. The 1947 Act confers power to restrict, control or prohibit or otherwise control imports and exports. Clause 6 1  of the 1968 order is as follows - The licensing authority may refuse to grant a licence if the licensing authority decides to canalize exports

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory provisions explicitly empower restriction, control, prohibition of exports and refusal of licences to canalise through specified agencies; precedents like Glass Chatons confirm validity.

holdings.text: The canalisation of export was held to be per se not an unreasonable restriction in the interest of the general public.

anchor.surface_text: if the scheme of canalisation of imports is in the interest of the general public the refusal of licence to outsiders would also be in the interest of the general public. The canalisation of import was held to be per se not an unreasonable restriction in the interest of the general public. Policies of imports or exports are fashioned not only with reference to internal or international trade but also on monetary policy, the development of agriculture and industries and even on the political policies of the country

holdings.reasoning_summary: Canalisation through state agency serves public interest in quality control, volume increase, economic policy; follows precedents like Glass Chatons and Devdas; traders can participate via Corporation.

holdings.text: The contention that the impugned Notice showed preference for the Corporation in infringement of Article 14 is unsound.

anchor.surface_text: The contention that the impugned Notice showed preference for the Corporation in infringement of Article 14 is unsound. The Corporation is a State owned body. The Corporation is appointed to undertake this export scheme. No preference is shown to the, Corporation. Where canalisation is decided no licence is granted in favour of any one.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Corporation is state-owned agency for canalisation; total exclusion, no competition or choice among private parties.

holdings.text: The Press Note made it clear that the State did not want to disturb the market but intended to save the trade and to prevent a loss to the sellers.

anchor.surface_text: The Press Note made it clear that the State did not want to disturb the market but intended to save the trade and to prevent a loss to the sellers. The State did not want to dislocate the commitments made by the traders to foreign buyers. This is precisely why the Press Note stated that the Corporation was prepared to enter into contract with foreign buyers and to export goods to them provided they opened letters of credit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No vested right to export post-canalisation; Press Note is concession to avoid hardship, not transfer of business or goodwill.

holdings.text: The service charges are nothing but quid pro quo for the services rendered by the Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: The service charges are nothing but quid pro quo for the services rendered by the Corporation. Counsel for the petitioner contended that the levy of service charges was not authorised by the 1947 Act which permitted only levy of fee in respect of applications for issue or renewal of licence. The Corporation is a licensee under the 1947 Act and the 1968 Order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charges by commercial state undertaking for services provided; not a governmental tax under Article 265.

holdings.text: Therefore the opening of letters of credit has rational relationship with the object of the canalisation scheme and there is no violation of Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore the opening of letters of credit has rational relationship with the object of the canalisation scheme and there is no violation of Article 14. As a corollary to the fixation of 24 January, 1972 as the date counsel for the petitioner contended that the scheme would enable foreign buyers to sue for breach of contract.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fixing date re LC prevents antedating, specious contracts, evasion; rational nexus to scheme objectives like preventing smuggling, under-invoicing.

holdings.text: Therefore, there is intelligible differentia between mica powder on the one hand and mica scrap and waste on the other, in excluding mica powder, from the canalisation scheme.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, there is intelligible differentia between mica powder on the one hand and mica scrap and waste on the other, in excluding mica powder, from the canalisation scheme. The State issued another Trade Notice on 20 April. 1972. This April 1972 Notice is also impeached. Under the April Notice which can be described as the second impugned Notice it is stated that the canalisation scheme Provided in the impugned Notice of 29 January, 1972

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exclusion promotes nascent mica powder industry; intelligible differentia with rational nexus to policy.

holdings.text: In this background it cannot be said that the Government authorities acted mala fide in extending the date of the opening of the letter of credit from 24 January, 1972 to 31 March, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: In this background it cannot be said that the Government authorities acted mala fide in extending the date of the opening of the letter of credit from 24 January, 1972 to 31 March, 1972. The relaxation was to minimise hardships to the traders. The relaxation was to prevent dislocation of trade on a large scale.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Response to traders' representations evidencing hardships; no evidence of prior knowledge or favouritism to influential persons.

anchor.surface_text: This contention is also unsound. Ordinarily, the import or export of goods under international contracts of sale frequently requires, in modern times, the permission of a governmental authority in the form of import or export licence. Where this is the case, the parties will usually provide in the contract which of them is to apply for the necessary licences and what is to happen if the application is refused.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Export contracts subject to licence laws; prohibition excuses non-performance; duty typically on seller.

holdings.text: For these reasons, the contentions of the petitioner fail. The petition is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons, the contentions of the petitioner fail. The petition is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of canalisation of export through the Corporation is pursuance to section 3 1   a  of the 1947 Act and clause 6 1  of the 1968 Order. The 1947 Act confers power to restrict, control or prohibit or otherwise control imports and exports. Clause 6 1  of the 1968 order is as follows - The licensing authority may refuse to grant a licence if the licensing authority decides to canalize exports
The petition is dismissed.

edges.explanation: Holding clarifies Press Note's intent to save trade and prevent loss without disturbing market, directly addressing issue on whether pre-canalisation procedure transfers business or goodwill.

anchor.surface_text: The Press Note made it clear that the State did not want to disturb the market but intended to save the trade and to prevent a loss to the sellers. The State did not want to dislocate the commitments made by the traders to foreign buyers. This is precisely why the Press Note stated that the Corporation was prepared to enter into contract with foreign buyers and to export goods to them provided they opened letters of credit.
The petition is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The service charges are nothing but quid pro quo for the services rendered by the Corporation. Counsel for the petitioner contended that the levy of service charges was not authorised by the 1947 Act which permitted only levy of fee in respect of applications for issue or renewal of licence. The Corporation is a licensee under the 1947 Act and the 1968 Order.
The petition is dismissed.
